ratings.comment: Professor Lin is one of the wisest men I've ever met.
I'm naturally bad at modern physics, and this guy's lectures and lecture notes can be extremely confusing at times. Read the textbook for sure.

Took class for a few weeks but ended up dropping. I'm not a fan of his teaching style one bit. Textbook only used for homework and not very helpful. Lectures are him rattling off his own notes and writing it down by hand. No demonstrations. No interaction. Discussion is hijacked as another lecture. Tests involve rewriting his class notes. Take 241.

He's fine if you go in for help, but his lectures are incredibly dry and there are no studying resources aside from his lecture notes since the book is not very similar to his teaching. I'd avoid him if possible. His main redeeming quality is that his sweater game is on point.

Professor Lin is a masterful lecturer and an absolutely phenomenal professor. Would not want to be taught this course by anyone else.  Not necessarily the easiest Professor, but that's not why we are here!
Avoid him like a plague. Way too old, slow and arrogant. Very much self-important. Take the class from Daniel Chang if you can. Dan is much more knowledgable, clear and humble.

Great professor, really stresses knowledge of material.  Memorizing equations is not enough to do well on exams.  Homework isn't too hard and is the only reason you need the book, and he is very willing to help you with it.  Curves to a B average which is nice.  Pop quizzes during lecture (you automatically get 15/20 for being there).
C.C. is possibly the coolest guy in the world... and a great teacher
Lin is the bomb.  If there was a rating for awesomeness everyone would be giving him a 5.  exams are somewhat difficult but directly ask about lecture problems so take lots of notes
okay in lecture, doesn't really interact with the students... but still fairly easy to get concepts. Exams are way different and harder than the homework. Very little partial credit on exams.

Really cool guy. Relates lazers to parents giving you money for beer, relates semiconductors to football, overall funny guy. His accent isn't too bad. The class isn't easy, he gives little partial credit, and his exams cover EVERYTHING that he talks about in class (and you must explain your answers EXACTLY how he explains things in class).

Great guy, makes the class very interesting. Try to show up on time for his class and go ask questions. If you show interest in his class he'll show interest in you doing well in his class. Either way exams can be tough, with little help from the book. Learned a ton!

I'll admit he is a good lecturer, but I still don't think I would recommend taking his class. His exams are completely different from the homework, you have to memorize little nuances in your notes in order to do well on the exams. He also gives little partial credit on exams.

My class size was small, and he took a persoanl interest in most students who deserved it. He is very funny, and has a lot of first hand expirence in physics. I had no trouble undertanding him through his accent after a week or so.
Ach! Avoid like the plague!
Really funny guy, great teacher.  "I was happy to find that semiconductors have some linkage to football"

Great professor.  One of the most helpful I have ever had.  The class can require a good deal of studying so be prepared.  Lecture is not required but highly recommended as he will give quizzes, sometimes the day after he just gave one, that are worth 20 points toward your grade.  He also makes lecture interesting with his stories and jokes.

Best physics teacher I've had at Madison! He is quite easy, especially his "pop" quizzes which anyone with a brain stem could pass. Tests are not too bad, and are straight from the homework. If you study from the cheat sheet he gives you, then you'll do just fine on exams. Careful though he grades hard.

C.C. Lin hates engineers.  He is hard if you don't care about nitty-gritty physics.  GO TO CLASS EVERYDAY AND TAKE NOTES for several reasons. 1) he gives pop quizzes. 2) he covers things that are not in the book. 3) his exam questions literally draw directly from lecture, i.e. "do this problem as done in lecture." If you take good notes, ur fine.

He's a funny professor and keeps my attention well during lectures. The exams are somewhat difficult (he's a bit picky), but it isn't too difficult to pull off a B or higher. The textbook can be largely ignored except for homework problems. He has a lot of trouble answering student's questions, however, so make a friend that you can study with.

He is a good professor. The material is not that complex and explains the subject matter well. He grades hard, but is entertaining enough to make it worth going to lectures. He mainly relies upon his notes for making test, so make sure you go to lectures and take good notes. HW is not that hard but is very helping in preparing for the tests.
The way he said "wavefunction" simply got me soaking.  Easiest professor evar.  Weekly 81x81 matrices took only 10 minutes to complete.
